mxCell.value: Webhook :- Its HTTP based callback function that allows you light weight event-driven communication between two apis
Event-Driven communication :- Notification System
Message-broker :- It allows an application services to communicate with each-other and exchange the data
What is message queue and need ? :-  Asynchronous nature,  pace matching,
What is message queue and need ? :-  It stores all the messages into queus and execute as per index, like that cab driver and user

What is point 2 point :-  
Like that if nay msg comes into the queue so it executed by consumer either consumer 2
What is pub/sub :-  In this case same message consumed by all the consumer based on the exchange logic
What we can do with exchange logic :-  Exchange brodcast the message to all the queues
How message queue works :-  kafka and rabbit mq
KAFKA :-  Producer, Consumer, Consumer Group, topic, partition, Offset, broker,  clustor, Zookeeper and may componants
Different partion read by different consumer
<font color="#ff9999">One Partition Can Work only with One consumer in a Consumer Group but any partition can work with another Consumer group consumer</font>
What happen if queue size limit is reached :-  We have different different broker because of each machine have limited size. We can increase the limit of machine with increasing the Broker
What happen when queue goes down :-  Queu has leader and follower so if the leader will goes down then rest of work done by follower

What happen when consumer goes down :- if the consumer 1 will be down in  between the process with perticular partion then the particular partion will be contact to any other free consumer in any group through the kafka and the remaining message will be fullfilled by newly connected consumer.
What happen when consumer not able to process messages :-

Msg basic structure :-  
Key: May be id
Value: Actual msg(*)
Partition: 
Topic: Topic name(*)
Round Robin fashion:-  Whenever partition is not decided then message goes to all the partition

Zookeeper :-  it will monitor the process that how much msg executed by consumer and also read the topic and partition and consumer and consumer group and after that commited offset decide that how much msg processed.
Topic :-  This is placeholder for the partition. It can have my partition
Offset :-  It is Monitor that how much msg read. Or yet to be read. Using commited offset variable
Broker:-  It is Server.
Cluster:-  It is Server.
Leader:-  The topic that is not replica called leader.
Follower:-  Replica Called followers.
Need of struture :-  Whenever leader goes down then replica takes over and replica become a leader. So all the messages countinue transfer from leader to replica

What happen when consumer not able to process messages :-  So if there is any bugs in messages in the partition so in this case consumer have to be retry for 3 times. and it will be not effect the commit offset count. if counts will reached to its maximum limit then the perticuler msg goes to the new queue the name of that queue is failure or dead letter queue. and it will count into commited offset. exp- if the commited offset 3 before retry then after sending into failure queue commited offset is 4. (Commited offset is not affected by retry count)
Rabbit MQ :- Pushed based approach
Kafka :-  Pull based approach
Rabbit MQ:-  Approach

FanOut

It brodcast the same messages to all the queue. if the queue is connected with the same exchange.

Direct exchange

IF the message key 1 and route key 1 then its binding to the the perticuler queue with msg key

Topic exchnage


if anything matches with the wild card then its bind with the perticuler queue

Message flow


if any msg faild then the perticuler msg goes to the starting index of the queue its called msg requeue and in the kafla its handle by offset and if reached the limit then goes to failure queue

gRPC :-  gRPC is a modern open source high performance Remote Procedure Call (RPC) framework that can run in any environment. It can efficiently connect services in and across data centers with pluggable support for load balancing, tracing, health checking and authentication. It is also applicable in last mile of distributed computing to connect devices, mobile applications and browsers to backend services.


1- Simple service definition
2- Start quickly and scale
3- Works across languages and platforms
4- Bi-directional streaming and integrated auth

Protocol buffers :- Protocol buffers are Google’s language-neutral, platform-neutral, extensible mechanism for serializing structured data – think XML, but smaller, faster, and simpler. You define how you want your data to be structured once, then you can use special generated source code to easily write and read your structured data to and from a variety of data streams and using a variety of languages.
Unary RPC :- It based on single request and single response. The client sends streams of messages and server respond with the single message.

Synchronous and asynchronous RPCs :-  Synchronous RPC calls that block until a response arrives from the server are the closest approximation to the abstraction of a procedure call that RPC aspires to. On the other hand, networks are inherently asynchronous and in many scenarios it’s useful to be able to start RPCs without blocking the current thread.

Deadline or Timeout  :- gRPC allows clients to specify how long they are willing to wait for an RPC to complete before the RPC is terminated with a DEADLINE_EXCEEDED error. On the server side, the server can query to see if a particular RPC has timed out, or how much time is left to complete the RPC.
